skill.name: scanpy
skill.description: Standard single-cell RNA-seq analysis pipeline. Use for QC, normalization, dimensionality reduction (PCA/UMAP/t-SNE), clustering, differential expression, and visualization. Best for exploratory scRNA-seq analysis with established workflows. For deep learning models use scvi-tools; for data format questions use anndata.
skill.summary: Standard single-cell RNA-seq analysis pipeline. Use for QC, normalization, dimensionality reduction ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 228 static findings are false positives. This is a legitimate scientific computing skill for single-cell RNA-seq analysis. The scanner incorrectly flagged: markdown inline code formatting (backticks), file I/O functions for data reading, directory creation operations, and git tree hashes as C2 indicators. No malicious patterns, network exfiltration, or command injection risks exist after human evaluation.

content.value_statement: Single-cell RNA sequencing generates complex datasets requiring specialized analysis. This skill provides a complete workflow for quality control, dimensionality reduction, clustering, and visualization of single-cell gene expression data.
actual_capabilities: Load and preprocess single-cell data from 10X, h5ad, CSV formats
Perform quality control and filter low-quality cells and genes
Apply dimensionality reduction techniques including PCA, UMAP, and t-SNE
Identify cell clusters using Leiden and Louvain algorithms
Find marker genes and annotate cell types from gene expression
Generate publication-quality visualizations of single-cell data
limitations: Requires existing scanpy installation and dependencies
Processes local files only, no direct database connections
Does not include deep learning models (use scvi-tools for those)
Performance scales with available memory for large datasets

use_cases.title: Exploratory scRNA-seq analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze single-cell gene expression datasets to identify cell types, states, and populations.

use_cases.title: Marker gene discovery
use_cases.description: Identify differentially expressed genes between clusters and characterize cell populations.

use_cases.title: Visualization pipelines
use_cases.description: Generate UMAP, t-SNE, and other dimensionality reduction plots for publications.

prompt_templates.title: Load and inspect data
prompt_templates.prompt: Load my single-cell data from data.h5ad and show me the basic structure including cell and gene counts.

prompt_templates.title: QC and filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Run quality control on my dataset, filter cells with less than 200 genes or more than 5% mitochondrial reads, and generate QC plots.

prompt_templates.title: Cluster and annotate
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform clustering at resolution 0.5, generate UMAP visualization, and identify marker genes for each cluster.

prompt_templates.title: Full analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a complete scanpy workflow: QC, normalization, highly variable genes, PCA, neighbors, UMAP, Leiden clustering at resolution 0.8, and save results.

output_examples.input: Load my single-cell data and perform quality control
output: QC metrics: mean 1,542 genes per cell, 4.2% mitochondrial reads
After filtering: 2,987 cells x 15,432 genes (92% cells retained)
Saved QC violin plots to figures/qc_violin.pdf

output_examples.input: Run complete clustering and annotation workflow
output: Identified 12 cell clusters using Leiden algorithm
Generated UMAP visualization colored by cluster
Top marker genes identified for each cluster
Cell types annotated based on known marker expression

best_practices: Always save raw counts before filtering: adata.raw = adata
Validate clustering by checking known marker gene expression
Save intermediate results to avoid re-running long workflows
anti_patterns: Skipping quality control steps before downstream analysis
Using default clustering resolution without testing multiple values
Not visualizing data before and after filtering steps

faq.question: What file formats does scanpy support?
faq.answer: Scanpy supports h5ad, 10X Genomics MTX, HDF5, CSV, loom, and text files.

faq.question: How many neighbors should I use for UMAP?
faq.answer: Default is 10-30 neighbors. Lower values preserve local structure; higher values capture global patterns.

faq.question: Leiden vs Louvain clustering?
faq.answer: Leiden is recommended as it produces better-quality clusters and is more efficient than Louvain.

faq.question: How many PCs should I use?
faq.answer: Check the PCA variance ratio plot. Use PCs before the elbow, typically 30-50 for datasets with high variability.

faq.question: What is the mitochondrial threshold?
faq.answer: Typical threshold is 5-20%. Lower thresholds remove more cells; validate with known cell type markers.

faq.question: How to annotate cell types?
faq.answer: Use known marker genes for cell types. Visualize expression on UMAP and compare cluster marker genes to reference databases.
